On Fri, Apr 8, 2011 at 11:06 PM, joel278 <lehman.154@...> wrote:

>
>
> Hi John,
>
>
> > Actually, you (perhaps) are missing something. Resource Constraint. You
> > can only have so many organisms in a particular location. Population
> > density plays a role in biological evolution, indirectly, because of its
> > role in survival. An organism who evolves to occupy a different niche
> lives
> > to pass on its genes.
> >
>
> I agree that a population within a new niche tends to grow exponentially
> until at some point the niche becomes saturated and competition within the
> niche grows more intense. However, I don't think this hurts the argument
> that there may exist some optimal replicator or class of replicators (say
> bacteria), or refutes the fact that blue whales are far more inefficient
> replicators than bacteria.
>

That may depend on how you look at it.  If you think of it as an organism,
maybe.  If you think of it like a city, that is another situation all
together.  Think of how the organism as a whole serves as a haven for many
specialized cells.  It creates an environment that allows the individual
cells to thrive in an optimal environment for an extended lifetime.  The
organism as a whole manages to withstand environmental changes far better
than a single-celled organism can.

And since change is constant (tides, days, seasons, and various other
catastrophic periodic upheavals) on this planet, an organism that can
survive those changes has an advantage.

The point to be made is, measuring only raw ability to pass on one's genes
to the next generation during a small period of time, without regards for
what is going to happen tomorrow is not a fair assessment of the reality of
the way biological life is evaluated.  One unexpected frost can devastate a
population of single-celled organisms that can't withstand being frozen.

Even if resources were infinite and there was no density-dependent
> selection, it is still true that an organism that evolves to occupy a
> different niche will still live to pass on its genes. That is, founding new
> niches is not directly caused by densisty-dependence or escaping
> competition; it would still happen regardless as long as the new niche was a
> viable way of life.
>

In theory, yes.  In practice, it provides an impetus, making it more likely.

 There are many elements of natural evolution, and one of our challenges in
> EC is to distill the essential elements of natural evolution that lead to
> interesting open-ended complexity growth from those elements that are merely
> incidental. By doing so we can achieve a deeper understanding of why natural
> evolution works and perhaps bend evolution to create massively complex
> artifacts in domains other than Earth.
>

Agreed.


>  So, modelling various aspects of the real world, such as geographic
> density of various organisms and resource constraints, may be essential
> features of creative evolution, or alternatively they could merely be
> incidental -- something present in nature, but not necessary for creating
> algorithmic explosions of complexity in the spirit of natural evolution.
>

I remember reading that the best models ever created for modeling traffic
flow ended up being a model of individual agents, each following a routine,
obeying rules, being as optimal as it knows how.  The combined behavior ends
up being fairly accurate at modeling the behavior of the real world.
Imagine that!  How much time did they waste trying to model it any other
way?  You would think that it would have been self-evident that modeling it
the way it really is would give the best results.

There is actually more to biological evolution than mere chance mutations.
There is also the "expression" and "suppression" of genes, and a means of
turning them on and off even during a single lifetime, giving an individual
organism a greater adaptability.  There are a host of mechanisms at work
that play into the expression of those genes.  There is the mechanistic
relationship between the structure of the encoding and the way they unfold.
To make a long story short, there is more to it than we typically encode in
a simulation, including aspects that are responsible for biological success
rates that we can not duplicate in our simulations.

If the goal is to duplicate nature's success rates, without necessarily
duplicating natures methods, we should probably seek to better understand
the relationship between the problem and the solution.  I put forth that DNA
is not just an arbitrary string of letters that have no bearing on reality.
That when there is no physical, biological impetus to evolve, there is very
little biological evolution.  That when there is a strong need, evolution
kicks into overdrive.  That the percentage of "successful" or at least
biologically viable mutations is way too high to be attributable to random
chance.  That there must be a mechanism at work there that we have not
identified yet.  That when we understand those principles, we can probably
employ them in a simulation that bears very little resemblance to the real
world, and still achieve open-ended and highly sophisticated evolved
solutions.  But we won't get there by randomness by itself.

>
> The argument is not that single-celled organisms can do everything that a
> human can do better, just that bacteria are *quantatively* better at the one
> measure central to evolution (and which is traditionally abstracted as a
> fitness function in EC): How well do you replicate (meet the objective)?
>

Maybe you make Ken's point by saying that.  Maybe in classic E.C., we are
notoriously bad at choosing an appropriate fitness function?

And you make my point, as well:  That is not the only "fitness" function
that Life uses.


> Traditional EAs converge and natural evolution diverges; the drive to
> diversity is such a fundamental part of natural evolution that it seems
> strange that our algorithms nearly always have the opposite property. This
> dissonance suggests there may be something fundamentally wrong with the
> dominant computational abstraction of natural evolution.
>

Well stated!

-- 
John Arrowwood
--
http://www.irie-inc.com/
http://www.FindingResonance.com/

--002354470f08c0324a04a07d4ab9
